messages.title: Use your powerzone
messages.text: MSD Prevention: Use your powerzone: Keeping items in your powerzone — the area from mid-thigh to mid-chest — helps you stay safe when lifting, lowering, and turning.

messages.title: Use the right PPE for MSD prevention
messages.text: MSD Prevention: The right equipment for the job: Using correct personal protective equipment (PPE) :gloves:, like gloves for proper grasping, reduces the risk of musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs) such as sprains and strains.

messages.title: Switch sides to reduce strain
messages.text: MSD Prevention: Switch sides: Alternating between your left and right sides helps your body maintain balance and reduces strain.

messages.title: Practise the team lift
messages.text: MSD Prevention: Practise the team lift: Test the weight before lifting and use both hands. Ask for help if an item is too heavy or awkward.

messages.title: Stretch it out
messages.text: MSD Prevention: Stretch it out: Stretch before and after work to reduce fatigue and improve range of motion.

messages.title: Select the right tool
messages.text: MSD Prevention: Select the right tool: Use the correct equipment in the proper way to reduce effort and avoid unnecessary strain.

messages.title: Reduce exposure to MSD risk factors
messages.text: MSD Prevention: Reduce exposure to MSD risk factors: Test the weight of items before lifting, keep them close to your body, and take micro-breaks to stretch while working.

messages.title: Empower associates to participate
messages.text: Safety Feedback Mechanism: Empower associates to participate: Create mechanisms for associates to raise safety concerns and suggestions. Make it easy for employees to report unsafe situations and provide feedback. Ensure diverse audiences (associates, operations leaders, and WHS team members) can engage across all business units and geographies.

messages.title: Close the feedback loop
messages.text: Safety Feedback Mechanism: Close the feedback loop: Provide feedback to associates on concerns or suggestions they have raised. Track concerns and suggestions to completion. Have follow-up conversations with associates on the status of their safety concerns or suggestions. This demonstrates that you value safety and builds trust with associates.

messages.title: Promote participation in feedback
messages.text: Safety Feedback Mechanism: Promote participation: Leaders should actively promote associate participation in safety feedback processes. Use multi-channel awareness and engagement activations (digital, static, and experiential learning experiences). Make safety feedback a regular part of daily safety conversations.

messages.title: Dragonfly program features
messages.text: Safety Feedback Mechanism: Dragonfly program features: Make reporting easy by ensuring Dragonfly kiosks are working properly and clearly signed. Enable one-click safety suggestions and concerns submission and allow associates to report using any device through digital reporting. Provide real-time visibility so associates can view the status of all their safety suggestions and concerns, track progress, and receive notifications when statuses have been updated or closed out. Managers provide direct feedback on actions being taken and use the AUSTIN system to notify managers of safety observations.

messages.title: Structured feedback collection
messages.text: Safety Feedback Mechanism: Structured feedback collection: Use multiple feedback channels, including skip-level initiatives for Operations Managers, Gemba Walks to identify safety concerns, and Voice of Associate (VOA) MyVoice for systematic feedback collection. Implement VOA boards, ASC boards, and stand-up audits. The safety team receives all feedback through safety channels, aligns with leadership on priorities to action, and conducts dive-deep analysis on all safety questions to understand results and identify opportunities by area, leader, or shift.

messages.title: Recognition and engagement
messages.text: Safety Feedback Mechanism: Recognition and engagement: Reward participation through recognition programs and use gamification to encourage involvement. Issue awards for safety contributions and share success stories and positive safety behaviors through stand-ups and communication boards.

messages.title: Encouraging associates to report safety issues
messages.text: Do you feel encouraged to report safety issues? Reporting safety concerns is not just encouraged — it is essential. Your willingness to speak up about potential hazards protects you, your colleagues, and everyone in our workplace. Multiple ways to report: You can raise safety concerns via direct conversations with your Area Manager or Team Lead, by participating in Safety Circles, contributing to Gemba Boards, using scanner message services in real-time, reviewing posters and briefs that list reporting methods at your site, and through Safety Saves/Solvers programs that recognise safety improvements.

messages.title: General conduct around conveyors
messages.text: Conveyor Safety: General conduct around conveyors: Never climb over or under the conveyor. Do not sit on the conveyor and never rest your hands on it. Never lean on, crawl, or reach under or over the conveyor. No joy riding on the conveyor. Only use designated stairways to go across the conveyor or walk around it — do not take shortcuts.

messages.title: Clothing and personal appearance
messages.text: Conveyor Safety: Clothing and personal appearance: Do not wear loose clothing on the shopfloor. Long hair and loose clothing can get entrapped in a conveyor and must be secured. Hair must be tied up at all times when on the operations floor, and ponytails reaching over the shoulders need to be pinned up while working. Beards exceeding 3 inches (7.6 cm) from the face must be tied up or netted. Avoid baggy clothing, jewellery, scarves, or accessories that can get caught in moving equipment. Badge lanyards must have a breakaway clasp so they safely detach if caught.

messages.title: Jam clearing
messages.text: Conveyor Safety: Jam clearing: Never attempt to correct conveyor faults on your own. Jam clearing is dangerous and only trained and authorized personnel should perform it. Never climb onto the conveyor in the event of a jam. Use jam poles to reach stuck packages and do not lean over the conveyor to reach packages. Report to your manager when you are unable to clear a blockage with a jam pole.

messages.title: Emergency procedures
messages.text: Conveyor Safety: Emergency procedures: Report problems with the conveyor to your supervisor immediately. Look out for the closest emergency shut-off device and remove any obstacles in front of it. Use the pull cord or emergency stop button in case of an emergency.

messages.title: Conveyor PPE
messages.text: Conveyor Safety: Personal protective equipment (PPE): Use only suitable and well-fitting PPE, including safety gloves and a high-visibility vest. Close your high-visibility vest and tuck away any strings, scarves, or lanyards. All badge lanyards worn on the operations floor must have a breakaway clasp for safe detachment if caught in moving equipment.

messages.title: Parcel handling on conveyors
messages.text: Conveyor Safety: Parcel handling: Slide parcels on conveyors rather than lift them. Keep your fingers clear of obstacles to allow parcels to fall safely into flex carts. Parcels falling from conveyors can cause impact injuries, so be aware of this hazard. Wait for packages to be in front of you before scanning to avoid over-reaching.

messages.title: General awareness around conveyors
messages.text: Conveyor Safety: General awareness: Malfunctions and potential hazards can occur quickly and must be reported immediately. Look out for the closest emergency shut-off device and remove any obstacles or clutter in front of it. Never take shortcuts — only use designated stairways to cross or walk around the conveyor.

messages.title: Layer up effectively
messages.text: Cold Stress Prevention: Layer up effectively: Wear moisture-wicking base layers, warm mid-layers, and a windproof outer layer to prevent heat loss in cold environments.

messages.title: Stay dry
messages.text: Cold Stress Prevention: Stay dry: Wet clothing increases heat loss dramatically. Change out of wet or damp gear as soon as possible to prevent cold stress.

messages.title: Use warm-up breaks
messages.text: Cold Stress Prevention: Use warm-up breaks: Take scheduled warm-up breaks in designated warm areas to restore core body temperature and reduce the risk of hypothermia.

messages.title: Know the symptoms
messages.text: Cold Stress Prevention: Know the symptoms: Shivering, numbness, fatigue, confusion, or slurred speech can be signs of cold stress. If you notice these in yourself or a colleague, report immediately and seek warmth.

messages.title: Protect extremities
messages.text: Cold Stress Prevention: Protect extremities: Wear insulated gloves, warm socks, and appropriate footwear to protect hands and feet, as they are the first areas to be affected by cold stress.
